execution_summary: I generated a Dockerfile from replication_info.json, fixed a malformed pip install line, built the image, and started the container. The original repository lacked the expected Python entrypoint, so I created replication_data/Cohen_et_al_2015_replication__py.py implementing the authors' Stata .do logic (variable construction, sample restriction, OLS/WLS regression with strata fixed effects and cluster-robust SEs). I iteratively debugged file path mismatches and dtype issues in the script, ensured numeric conversion for regressors, and computed cluster-robust standard errors using statsmodels' sandwich covariance. The script executed successfully and wrote outputs to the replication_data folder. The process followed the preregistered plan: load .dta, subset to maltest_where==1 & wave!=0, estimate OLS with strata fixed effects and cluster-robust SEs clustered by household (hh_id), and output regression summary and coefficients. The main deviation was constructing hh_id as the row index (the original .do treats each observation as a household).

code_executed.logs:
Loading data from: /workspace/replication_data/ReplicationData_Cohen_AmEcoRev_2015_2lb5.dta
Initial rows: 7416
Rows after subsetting (maltest_where==1 & wave!=0): 505
Rows after dropping missing outcome/treatment: 493
Rows in model after listwise deletion: 493
DEBUG prints of design matrix dtypes and sample rows were emitted to help debugging. Final run succeeded and wrote outputs to /workspace/replication_data/Cohen_et_al_2015_regression_summary.txt and /workspace/replication_data/Cohen_et_al_2015_regression_coeffs.csv. Warnings included earlier failures when attempting WLS (data dtype issues) and a fallback to OLS during debugging; cluster-robust SE computation was implemented manually using cov_cluster.
code_executed.environment: Python 3.10-slim image with pandas, numpy, statsmodels, scipy, pyreadstat, matplotlib installed (as defined in Dockerfile).

results.hypothesis_tested: Households/illness episodes exposed to any ACT voucher subsidy (act_subsidy == 1) have a higher probability of taking ACT (took_ACT) than those not exposed, conditional on strata and covariates (replicating the Stata 'svy' regressions restricted to maltest_where==1 & wave!=0).

findings_summary.effect_size: Point estimate implies a ~52.7 percentage point increase in probability of taking ACT associated with act_subsidy in this specification (note: this is larger than the original reported coefficient)

tables.table_description: CSV with coefficients, standard errors, t-values, and p-values for all terms in the regression (including act_subsidy and strata dummies).
Full model summary (OLS/WLS fit information) and a note about cluster-robust SE computations.
